text: <@U0B7VH143|raedur> has joined the channel
<@U0B82KN85|alexia> has joined the channel
<@U0B8MAHHQ|firstsputnik> has joined the channel

Any good reads on refactoring and adding tests to a legacy app? I have an old app in need of dire refactoring and tests, I have already had a read through MVP and MVVM patterns to help refactoring it but I am not sure about tests (I guess Robolectric could be an option?)
<@U09T8SFG8>: this is what I am currently doing, asked the same question a lot of months ago
Slowly refactoring bit by bit
Adding tests..eh.. unit tests aren’t possible in the current state.
I’d recommend doing what I’m doing. Extract parts into methods, refactor the rest, extract a bit of that method, refactor the rest, and so on and on.
who needs tests when you have manual QA with Microsoft Excel?
:smile:
but idk, I decided not to write espresso/robolectric tests currently due to changing layouts as I refactor

The app was written by a C++ dev using C++ conventions.... :stuck_out_tongue: I am actually quite new in testing in Android (I have experience with Java JUnit) but I have been listening to podcasts and reading to figure out a good way to do the testing, is there like a de facto way of doing testing? Like Robolectric or mockito perhaps?
Nah, everyone has their specific flavor
What I was thinking is to use the MVP pattern and for starters test only my Java code
so pretty much test my presenters
I prefer testing my presenters by using mockito and junit basically
imho that is the only thing I test, no really need for UI
Yeah I was thinking of doing the same, for starters at least to ease my way through this
Anyway I'll get on with this, thanks for the help
<@U0B8R3VV4|pakoito> has joined the channel
Does anyone use this? <http://androidannotations.org>
I’m curious about your thoughts
it’s been around for a while
a bit unstable IIRC
I would not recommend it
Why not?
Too heavy for what it tries to help you accomplish
Tell me more, i’m more interested in your opinion than just a straight up yay or nay
it only does *everything*, so the moment something goes wrong you can’t descale and reduce dependency on it
I’ll elaborate whenever I get back to the office.
but <@U0B8R3VV4> pretty much hit most of it from a structural standpoint in one sentence.
Yeah, I’m big on modularity
and the Unix philosophy
also, is it even maintained anymore
pretty much anything it can do can be done by a smaller more focused library

attachments.title: Regex101 - online regex editor and debugger
attachments.text: Regex101 allows you to create, debug, test and have your expressions explained for PHP, PCRE, JavaScript and Python. The website also features a community where you can share useful expressions.

```
final Observable<String> textChanges = RxTextView.textChanges(search)
                .debounce(700, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
                .filter(s -> s != null)
                .map(s -> s.toString().trim())
                .distinctUntilChanged()
                .subscribeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread());
```
